channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gang Leader From Mexico Gets Life Term
item.description: According to U.S. officials, Arturo Gallegos Castrellón, 35, ordered hundreds of killings as cartels battled over control of Ciudad Juárez.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: News Analysis: Wrong Guesses About North Korea Leave U.S. Struggling to Adjust
item.description: Almost everything American intelligence agencies and North Korea-watchers thought they understood two years ago about Kim Jong-un, the North’s young leader, turns out to have been wrong.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, on Thursday in front of female soldiers in a photo released by North Korea.

item.title: Russia to Start Drills, Warning Ukraine Over Mobilization
item.description: Russia announced military exercises along the border with Ukraine on Thursday, prompting a warning from Secretary of State John Kerry that Moscow would face additional sanctions if it does not act to ease tensions.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS, NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian activists seen at the checkpoint outside Slovyansk, where government forces conducted the counter-terrorism operation, Ukraine, Thursday.

item.title: Obama Suffers Setbacks in Japan and the Mideast
item.description: While offering security assurances to Japan, President Obama did not take sides over who has sovereignty over islands that are also claimed by China.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Obama offered a toast to Empress Michiko and Emperor Akihito of Japan during a state dinner at the Imperial Palace.

item.title: 2 Journalists in Lebanon Are Charged by Tribunal
item.description: The international tribunal dealing with the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister has charged two journalists with contempt of court and obstruction of justice over the publication of confidential information about possible witnesses.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Americans Die In Grim Trend In Afghanistan
item.description: Officials said the gunman appeared to be a police officer who reacted in the moment when he saw a small group of American visitors outside his guard post, raising fears of a new wave of so-called green-on-blue shootings spurred by deepening Afghan resentment.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and ALAN BLINDER
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel peered out a window outside of the hospital in Kabul where Americans were killed on Thursday.

item.title: Memo From Damascus: If Assad Wins War, Challenge From His Own Sect May Follow
item.description: Some loyalists of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria would be likely to push for a bigger share of power if they came to feel safe from the threat of insurgent revenge.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The site of a car bomb explosion in a mostly Alawite neighborhood of Homs, Syria, last week.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: 4 New Deaths Reported From Virus
item.description: In the past 24 hours, Saudi Arabia has reported four new deaths from a Middle East virus and 36 more cases of infection.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Election Violence in 2 Regions Leaves 7 Dead
item.description: A major day of voting in the world’s biggest elections was marred by violence on Thursday as gunmen killed four paramilitary soldiers and three polling officials who were traveling on buses after conducting balloting in two Indian states.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bomber Kills at Least 11 People South of Baghdad
item.description: A suicide bomber rammed his explosives-filled car into a police checkpoint south of Baghdad on Thursday, killing at least 11 people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Plan to Sell Condoms in Schools Encounters Resistance
item.description: Middle schools in Xi’an in Shaanxi Province should sell condoms, education officials have said. Family planning officials say they know the move is controversial, but hope it will help stop the spread of H.I.V.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Some teachers object that selling condoms in middle and high schools will only encourage promiscuity.

item.title: France Joins Gay Couples by Thousands, Amid Gripes
item.description: Despite the protests that accompanied passage of the law allowing same-sex marriage, more than 7,000 such ceremonies have been performed in the last year — sometimes by reluctant officiants.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Italy’s Mob Extends Reach in Europe
item.description: Organized crime groups, which many still view as mostly a southern Italian problem, have used their vast wealth to gain sway in both economic and government circles.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: French law enforcement officers stand guard as Antonio Lo Russo, a powerful leader of Italy's Camorra crime organization, arrives at the Court in Aix-en-Provence.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: June 4th Museum Set to Open in Hong Kong
item.description: A museum that aims to preserve memories of the 1989 Tiananmen protests is scheduled to open this weekend, despite the threat of a lawsuit from the building owners’ committee.
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Andrew Lam Hon-kin introduced a display of photographs featuring student protesters and the portrait of Mao Zedong at Tiananmen Square during a preview of the new June 4th Museum.

item.title: Climbers Leave Everest Amid Regrets and Tensions Among Sherpas
item.description: As most Western climbers decided to return home, they described a menacing atmosphere among Sherpas in base camp, including threats to those who planned to continue.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: World Briefing: China’s Legislature Votes to Toughen Environmental Protection Law
item.description: The revised law, which will take effect next year, will allow for stricter punishments of companies or individuals caught polluting the environment.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: The Lede: American Journalist Released by Ukraine Separatists
item.description: Separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine released the American journalist Simon Ostrovsky on Thursday, three days after he was taken prisoner in Slovyansk while reporting for Vice News.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.N. Finds Humanitarian Aid Still Blocked in Syria, Despite Resolution
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have no access to medical supplies, blocked by the warring sides, a report concludes.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A boy received humanitarian aid in Damascus last month.

item.title: Prosecutors Cite Stowage and Design in Korean Disaster
item.description: Prosecutors officially attributed the sinking of a South Korean ferry to an improper stowage of cargo and a loss of stability caused by a change in the vessel’s design.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and JIHA HAM
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parents of students whose bodies have not yet been recovered from the sunken South Korean ferry question Coast Guard officials at a temporary command center in Jindo, South Korea.

item.title: Alistair MacLeod, a Novelist in No Hurry, Dies at 77
item.description: Mr. MacLeod, a Canadian author, won the International Impac Dublin Literary Award in 2001 for his novel “No Great Mischief.”
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: As Wine Fetches Staggering Sums, Fakery Claims Rise
item.description: Connoisseurs driving up the prices of rare and collectible wines have spurred a wave of counterfeiters who target collectors eager to flaunt their trophies.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Stephen Williams, head of the Antique Wine Company of London, which is being sued by an Atlanta collector for $25 million.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 24
item.description: In the sixth phase of parliamentary elections on Thursday, 117 constituencies across 12 states went to the polls.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman showing her inked finger after casting her vote in Sawai Madhopur, Rajasthan, in the sixth phase of parliamentary elections.

item.title: Israel Halts Talks, Citing Palestinian Unity Agreement
item.description: The Israeli government said that it would not under any circumstances negotiate with a Palestinian government that was backed by Hamas, the militant Islamic group.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Voting Fraud Hangs Stubbornly Over Afghan Elections, With Runoff Likely
item.description: Preliminary election results, which are due Saturday, will not be official until the Electoral Complaints Commission rules on 746 complaints of serious fraud in the presidential race.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah during an interview at his residence in Kabul on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: The Autumn of a Patriarch
item.description: As Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the chief of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam in Tamil Nadu, plots a resurgence in the 2014 elections, there is the feeling that this may prove to be a comeback too far for the grand old man of Indian politics.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
